welcome.data: Warm-Up Prompt (10 minutes): “What do you think a game engine does? Can you name one or two games you think were made using a game engine?” Classroom discussion and responses on the board.

aim.data: Objective (3 minutes): Students will understand the goals of the course and be introduced to the Godot 4 interface, preparing to build their first scene.

review.data: Since this is the first session, review general computing principles students may have encountered: what a program is, what code does, and what a user interface is. Quick class poll: "Have you ever used Scratch, Python, or Roblox Studio before?"

relevant.data:
Mini-Lecture and Demo (20 minutes): Instructor walks through:
  • What is Godot? Overview and purpose of a game engine.
  • Installing and opening Godot 4
  • Creating a new project
  • Explanation of Godot's node-based system

Live Demo: Create a new Godot project titled HelloWorldGame. Show creation of root node Node2D, save the scene as Main.tscn. Explain how scenes and nodes work.

interactive.data:
Hands-On Activity (25 minutes): Students repeat the steps:
  • Open Godot and create a new project named FirstGame
  • Add a root Node2D and rename it to Main
  • Add a Label node as a child, change the text to “Hello, Godot!”
  • Run the scene
Walk around and help students troubleshoot any issues in Godot setup.

ownership.data: Student Reflections and Customization (15 minutes): Students change the label text to their name or a custom message. Encourage experimentation: change font size, color, or position of the label. Advanced students can add a second Label or Sprite node and modify its properties.

resonate.data: Exit Ticket (5 minutes): “What’s one thing you found interesting or confusing about Godot today?” Responses can be shared verbally or submitted via Google Form or notecard.

supplies.data:
- Computers with Godot 4 installed
- Projector for live demonstration
- Student notebooks or Google Docs
- Access to class LMS or shared folder for resources and exit ticket form
